<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/31  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 310, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 50 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 380, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(4x^{3} + ax^{2} + 5x + b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants, is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). It is given that \((2x + 1)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). When \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x - 4)\) the remainder is equal to 3 times the remainder when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x - 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 328, 155]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 97, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\int_{1}^{3}x^{2}\ln 3x \mathrm{d}x\). Give your answer in the form \(a\ln b + c\), where \(a\) and \(c\) are rational and \(b\) is an integer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 460, 92]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(\ln (x + y) = 3x^2y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 495, 124]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point (1, 0).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence or otherwise solve the equation \(\sec^4 2\alpha - \tan^4 2\alpha = 2\tan^2 2\alpha \sec^2 2\alpha\) for \(0^\circ < \alpha < 180^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 89, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation \(2 + \mathrm{e}^{-0.2x} = \ln (1 + x)\) has only one root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 146, 574]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 556, 589, 574]]<|/det|>
Show by calculation that this root lies between 7 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 354, 88]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 97, 603, 119]]<|/det|>
\[x_{n + 1} = \exp \bigl (2 + \mathrm{e}^{-0.2x_n}\bigr) - 1\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
to determine the root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
[exp(\(x\)) is an alternative notation for \(\mathrm{e}^{x}\).]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 85, 692, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = \sin 2x(1 + \sin 2x)\), for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{3}{4}\pi\), and its minimum point \(M\). The shaded region bounded by the curve that lies above the \(x\)-axis and the \(x\)-axis itself is denoted by \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 317, 148, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 317, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
Given that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\) lies in the interval \(\frac{1}{2}\pi < x < \frac{3}{4}\pi\), find the exact coordinates of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[900, 333, 922, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 430, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of the region \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 78, 336, 117]]<|/det|>
Let \(\mathrm {f}(x)=\frac {5x^{2}+8x+5}{(1+2x)(2+x^{2})}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 133, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 410, 152]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathrm {f}(x)\) in partial fractions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 603, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence find the coefficient of \(x^{3}\) in the expansion of \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 103, 915, 119]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 97, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Given that \(z = 1 + yi\) and that \(y\) is a real number, express \(\frac{1}{z}\) in the form \(a + bi\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are functions of \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 97, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 185, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 500, 803, 523]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\left(a - \frac{1}{2}\right)^2 + b^2 = \frac{1}{4}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are the functions of \(y\) found in part (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 501, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 143, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 235, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
On a single Argand diagram, sketch the loci given by the equations \(\operatorname {Re}(z) = 1\) and \(\left|z - \frac{1}{2}\right| = \frac{1}{2}\), where \(z\) is a complex number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 266, 922, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 685, 146, 702]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
The complex number \(z\) is such that \(\operatorname {Re}(z) = 1\). Use your answer to part **(b)** to give a geometrical description of the locus of \(\frac{1}{z}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 702, 95]]<|/det|>
The position vector of point \(A\) relative to the origin \(O\) is \(\overrightarrow{OA} = 8\mathbf{i} - 5\mathbf{j} + 6\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 91, 636, 111]]<|/det|>
The line \(l\) passes through \(A\) and is parallel to the vector \(2\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + 4\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 123, 144, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 123, 379, 141]]<|/det|>
State a vector equation for \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 123, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 186, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 918, 437]]<|/det|>
The position vector of point \(B\) relative to the origin \(O\) is \(\overrightarrow{OB} = - t\mathbf{i} + 4t\mathbf{j} + 3t\mathbf{k}\), where \(t\) is a constant. The line \(l\) also passes through \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 306, 467]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The line \(m\) has vector equation \(\mathbf{r} = 5\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k} + \mu (\mathbf{a}\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} + 3\mathbf{k})\). The acute angle between the directions of \(l\) and \(m\) is \(\theta\), where \(\cos \theta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 126, 384, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 102, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 81, 636, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
A large cylindrical tank is used to store water. The base of the tank is a circle of radius 4 metres. At time \(t\) minutes, the depth of the water in the tank is \(h\) metres. There is a tap at the bottom of the tank. When the tap is open, water flows out of the tank at a rate proportional to the square root of the volume of water in the tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 144, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 584, 384]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{\mathrm{d}t} = -\lambda \sqrt{h}\), where \(\lambda\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 364, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 910, 89]]<|/det|>
At time \(t = 0\) the tap is opened. It is given that \(h = 4\) when \(t = 0\) and that \(h = 2.25\) when \(t = 20\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Solve the differential equation to obtain an expression for \(t\) in terms of \(h\), and hence find the time taken to empty the tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
